SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: According to the narrator, what makes playing basketball appealing?

A.Choice: She likes the feeling of knowing exactly what to do when she plays basketball.

B.Choice: She feels the skills needed for playing basketball are simple to master.

C.Choice: She thinks that when she plays basketball she is likely to succeed.

D.Choice: She gets to be like her brothers when she plays basketball.

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: According to the narrator, why is basketball “as good as Shakespeare” (lines 16 and 17)?

A.Choice: It connects her to important people.

B.Choice: It helps her to understand her life.

C.Choice: It has the power to strongly affect her.

D.Choice: It helps her deal with disappointments in life.

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Based on lines 20 through 29, what can readers conclude about the narrator's father?

A.Choice: He thinks boys and girls should pursue different activities.

B.Choice: He believes that siblings should support one another.

C.Choice: He values sports more than he values education.

D.Choice: He wishes that all of his children were boys.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: What does the narrator discover in lines 30 through 36 that affects the plot of the story?

A.Choice: Watching basketball gives her the same feeling as studying.

B.Choice: She wants other people to pay more attention to her.

C.Choice: She is jealous of the opportunity her brother has.

D.Choice: Her passion for basketball is overwhelming.

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: How does the incident described in lines 53 through 59 affect the story?

A.Choice: It shows how the narrator and her family attempt to compromise.

B.Choice: It escalates the conflict so that the father is forced to make a choice.

C.Choice: It reveals the influence the mother and brother have on the father's behavior.

D.Choice: It demonstrates the father's beliefs and his realization that his beliefs are wrong.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast the structure of two or more texts and analyze how the differing structure of each text contributes to its meaning and style.
Content: How does the structure of the story contribute to its meaning?

A.Choice: The narrator describes how she differs from her brothers, which leads to a conflict with her father.

B.Choice: The narrator expresses her point of view, which provides background for the conflict with her father.

C.Choice: The narrator describes her frustration with life at home and school, which leads to problems with her father.

D.Choice: The narrator begins with a reflection on rules, which leads to an improvement in her relationship with her father.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: How does the basketball game setting relate to a theme of the story?

A.Choice: by showing where the narrator feels the most alive

B.Choice: by showing how the narrator utilizes her knowledge

C.Choice: by showing how the narrator differs from other girls

D.Choice: by showing why the narrator supports her brother

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: Read these sentences from line 3.
:box:My friends were fond of practical jokes. I do not care to know people who are not.
These statements impact the story by explaining

A.Choice: why the narrator laughs so hard at dinner

B.Choice: the narrator's presence at the dinner

C.Choice: the narrator's reason for suspicion

D.Choice: why the guests embraced him

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: What does the phrase “as a dog scents game” in line 14 of the story suggest about the narrator's actions?

A.Choice: He is enjoying the laughter of the other guests.

B.Choice: He feels on the verge of finding the prankster.

C.Choice: He feels left out of the dinner conversation.

D.Choice: He is alert to some hidden plan.

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Read lines 14 and 15 of the story.
:box:I did not let a word, or a meaning, or a gesture escape me.
This sentence suggests that the narrator

A.Choice: feels anxious about his current situation

B.Choice: is highly critical of his friends' interactions

C.Choice: feels defenseless against the coming events

D.Choice: is too distracted to join his friends' conversation

SubTopics: Analyze how particular lines of dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision.
Content: How do lines 25 through 33 build suspense?

A.Choice: They suggest that someone is looking in the window.

B.Choice: They extend the narrator's search for deceit.

C.Choice: They indicate unusual details about the room.

D.Choice: They reveal the narrator's fear of the dark.

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: Which words reveal the irony of the narrator's situation?

A.Choice: “I thought: 'Here are people who have more than their share of amusement, and apparently without reason. They must have planned some good joke.” (lines 9 through 11)

B.Choice: “The hour struck for retiring; and the whole household came to escort me to my room.” (line 17)

C.Choice: “However, the night was advancing; and I ended by coming to the conclusion that I was foolish.” (lines 35 and 36)

D.Choice: “The precautions I had taken in closing the shutters and going to sleep in the middle of the room had only brought about the practical joke I had been trying to avoid.” (lines 68 and 69)

SubTopics: Analyze how differences in the points of view of the characters and the audience or reader (e.g., created through the use of dramatic irony) create such effects as suspense or humor.
Content: What effect does the point of view of the story have on the reader?

A.Choice: The point of view increases suspense by limiting the reader to the narrator's understanding of events.

B.Choice: The point of view creates humor by showing how the narrator's friends misunderstand him.

C.Choice: The point of view raises the reader's sympathy for the questions the narrator faces.

D.Choice: The point of view adds to the reader's mistrust of what the narrator reports.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to the characters, setting, and plot; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which detail best expresses a theme of the story?

A.Choice: “One autumn I went to spend the hunting season with some friends ...” (line 1)

B.Choice: “Assuredly I am to be the victim ...” (line 11)

C.Choice: “I heard persons moving about outside my door.” (line 23)

D.Choice: “For at least another hour I remained awake, starting at the slightest sound.” (line 51)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: Which words from the article provide the best clue to the meaning of the word “tedious” in line 3?

A.Choice: “Confession Time” (line 1)

B.Choice: “head flat on desk” (lines 1 and 2)

C.Choice: “takes an eternity to tick by” (line 4)

D.Choice: “You begin to wish you had your cell phone” (lines 4 and 5)

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Read this sentence from line 6 of the article.
:box:Boredom is the enemy of fun.
Which quotation best helps the reader understand this sentence?

A.Choice: “If fun is the big drop of a roller coaster, boredom is waiting in line.” (line 7)

B.Choice: “If we want to figure out the future of fun, we have to first figure out how to end boredom.” (line 8)

C.Choice: “Imagine that: a world where each second is interesting and nothing is dull” (line 9)

D.Choice: “That sounds like science fiction, but new psychological research hints that being bored-even in class — may one day be a thing of the past.” (lines 9 through 11)

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).
Content: Lines 19 through 26 connect modern entertainment to boredom by suggesting that it causes us to

A.Choice: want more challenging games to play

B.Choice: misunderstand the role of fun in our lives

C.Choice: develop expectations for high levels of excitement

D.Choice: avoid adapting to new technological innovations

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).
Content: How does Professor Eastwood's work differ from previous research?

A.Choice: by attempting to create a new definition for boredom

B.Choice: by failing to look into a connection to brain activity

C.Choice: by focusing on the human attention system

D.Choice: by using data from earlier studies on boredom

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Content: Read lines 9 through 1 of the article.
:box:That sounds like science fiction, but new psychological research hints that being bored-even in class — may one day be a thing of the past.
Which quotation provides the best evidence to support this claim?

A.Choice: “... less than one in 20 adults were bored at work.” (lines 15 and 16)

B.Choice: “... our brains adapt really quickly to certain levels of stimulation ...” (lines 23 and 24)

C.Choice: “... anything the attention system in your brain locks onto will be automatically sucked up into your conscious awareness ...” (lines 43 and 44)

D.Choice: “Each of us has the ability to make every situation interesting; all we need to do is change the way we look at it ...” (lines 61 and 62)

SubTopics: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: The final sentence in lines 68 and 69 best contributes to the article by

A.Choice: suggesting that the author often fell asleep in classes

B.Choice: connecting the information to the incident described at the beginning

C.Choice: encouraging students to stay awake and avoid boredom in class

D.Choice: emphasizing that teenagers are often more bored than other groups

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which sentence states a central idea that is supported throughout the article?

A.Choice: Modern entertainment decreases boredom.

B.Choice: Boredom is present in teenagers more than in adults.

C.Choice: Everyone experiences boredom occasionally.

D.Choice: People have the ability to control their boredom.

SubTopics: Analyze how a text makes connections among and distinctions between individuals, ideas, or events (e.g., through comparisons, analogies, or categories).
Content: How was CATIA essential to the success of Gehry's plan for the museum?

A.Choice: It helped him find less expensive materials.

B.Choice: It allowed him to work earlier ideas into his design.

C.Choice: It suggested unique materials to use for construction.

D.Choice: It allowed him to add less-common shapes into his design.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph in a text, including the role of particular sentences in developing and refining a key concept.
Content: What do lines 25 through 30 contribute to the development of ideas in the article?

A.Choice: They explain a way of thinking that allowed an obstacle to be overcome.

B.Choice: They show how preferences in the shapes of buildings have changed.

C.Choice: They describe a step in the building process.

D.Choice: They illustrate how different artists work.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone, including analogies or allusions to other texts.
Content: The phrase “waved a magic wand” (line 40) suggests that the

A.Choice: museum fulfilled the city's wishes

B.Choice: project's success amazed many people

C.Choice: project succeeded in part because of luck

D.Choice: museum resembled a creation from a fairy tale

SubTopics: Cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: According to the article, what quality is the author referring to by comparing the Bilbao museum to the Eiffel Tower and the Pyramids (lines 67 through 69)?

A.Choice: the impact of its height

B.Choice: the ability to generate revenue

C.Choice: the effort needed to construct it

D.Choice: the widespread amazement felt about it

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of using different mediums (e.g., print or digital text, video, multimedia) to present a particular topic or idea.
Content: Which phrase has the strongest connection to the photo?

A.Choice: “... someone must have waved a magic wand.” (line 40)

B.Choice: “... blossoming like silver petals ...” (line 48)

C.Choice: “... connecting the urban fabric of a fairly dense city ...” (lines 52 and 53)

D.Choice: “I'm trying to get more liquid ...” (line 83)

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which sentence best supports the central idea of the article?

A.Choice: “Three architects from Austria, Japan, and the United States were invited to submit proposals.” (lines 12 and 13)

B.Choice: “Gehry already had used CATIA for parts of several other buildings, including Fred and Ginger in Prague.” (lines 22 and 23)

C.Choice: “Instead more than a million came to marvel at the titanium-clad miracle.” (lines 64 and 65)

D.Choice: “However, he admits feeling pleased when people on the streets of Bilbao come up and give him a hug.” (lines 79 and 80)

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.
Content: Which information would be most important to include in a summary of the article?

A.Choice: “Shipyards sat idle; steel mills, silent.” (lines 3 and 4)

B.Choice: “Their master plan included a first-class museum, so original that it would attract worldwide attention and rescue their town from its slow decline.” (lines 6 through 8)

C.Choice: “You find his fish motif appearing here and there throughout the museum.” (lines 55 and 56)

D.Choice: “At seventy Gehry finds his creativity is speeding up.” (line 81)

Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Stranger from the Tonto,” how do lines 23 through 26 contribute to the plot? Use two details from the story to support your response.

Content: How does Jenester influence the decisions of the men in the story? Use two details from the story to support your response.

Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Content: In the story, Saeng and her mother discuss hibiscus plants. What does the hibiscus plant represent to Saeng? What does it represent to Saeng's mother? What thoughts and feelings do Saeng and her mother have about the hibiscus plant in the story? Use details from the story to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• explain what the hibiscus plant represents to Saeng
• explain what the hibiscus plant represents to Saeng's mother
• explain the thoughts and feelings Saeng and her mother have about the hibiscus plant in the story
• use details from the story to support your response

Content: What impact does the statement “I felt like a genie on a flying carpet” (line 15) have on the story? Use two details from the story to support your response.

Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Tracks,” how does the narrator's point of view create wonder? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text.

Content: Explain why the presence of “ghost nets” in the ocean is an important problem to solve. Use two details from the article to support your answer.

Content: According to “Too Many Fishermen,” what is the main reason previously abundant marine environments have declined? Use two details from the article to support your answer.

Content: The author of “Too Many Fishermen” describes certain place-names as “ghostly reminders.” What does the author mean by using the words “ghostly reminders”? Use two details from the article to support your answer.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content.
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression.
Content: “Monster Debris” and “Too Many Fishermen” both indicate that human beings are having a negative impact on ocean life. How does each author support this claim? Describe the evidence each author uses and evaluate the relevance and strength of the evidence. Use details from both articles to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• identify the support given in each article that shows the negative impact human beings have had on the ocean environment
• evaluate the effectiveness, strength, and relevance of the support
• use details from both articles to support your response
